Public

ImagPhotonics.ONEFORTH ‚Äî Constant

A constant representing one-fourth (0.25).

source
ImagPhotonics.ONEHALF ‚Äî Constant

A constant representing one-half (0.5).

source
ImagPhotonics.AbstractComponent ‚Äî Type
abstract type AbstractComponent{T<:Unitful.Quantity} end

Represents a generic photonic component type with dimensions and units specified in the type signature. The dimensions and unit cannot be an empty set.

The type parameter T<:Unitful.Quantity. The layer type is used for representation in the GDSII files, and the datatype is used to define the material parameters.

See also Waveguide, Taper, Device, IIDD

source
ImagPhotonics.AbstractConnectorFunction ‚Äî Type
abstract type AbstractConnectorFunction<:AbstractIsoparametricFunction end

Represents a generic connector function type, which is a subtype of AbstractIsoparametricFunction. It is used to define the connection between photonic components.

source
ImagPhotonics.AbstractIsoparametricFunction ‚Äî Type
abstract type AbstractIsoparametricFunction end

Represents a generic isoparametric function type, with the order defined in the type signature. The order is allowed to be an empty set, in which case a default linear isoparametric function is returned.

source
ImagPhotonics.Connector_Type ‚Äî Type

An enumeration representing the connector type for a photonic device.

  • C_INPUT: Indicates the port is an input port.
  • C_OUTPUT: Indicates the port is an output port.
source
ImagPhotonics.Device ‚Äî Type
mutable struct Device

A mutable struct representing a 2D photonic device. It inherits from AbstractComponent. It generated the photonic structure used in the optimization process.

The type parameter T<:Unitful.Quantity.

Fields

  • width::T : Width of the device.
  • length::T : Length of the device.
  • curvature_left::T : Curvature on the left side of the device.
  • curvature_right::T : Curvature on the right side of the device.
  • curvature_up::T : Curvature on the top side of the device.
  • curvature_down::T : Curvature on the bottom side of the device.
  • number_waveguides::NTuple{2,Union{Int,Vector{Int}}} : Tuple containing the number of input and output waveguides.
  • location::NTuple{2,Union{LocationType,Vector{LocationType}}} : Tuple containing the location of input and output waveguides.
  • points::Array{T, 2} : The array representing the device points.
  • pin::Vector{Port} : The vector representing the input ports of the device.
  • pout::Vector{Port} : The vector representing the output ports of the device.
  • shape_function::ShapeFunction2D : The shape function used for the device.
  • layer::Int : The layer for the device.
  • datatype::Int : The datatype for the device.

Constructor

Device(length, width; number_waveguides=(4,4),spacing=(5.0u"Œºm",5.0u"Œºm"),
location=(Location_Type(0),Location_Type(1)), 
curvature_left=0.0u"Œºm", curvature_right=0.0u"Œºm", 
curvature_up  =0.0u"Œºm", curvature_down =0.0u"Œºm",
layer=0, datatype=1)

Generates a device with number_waveguides input and output for gdsii files and photonic computations.

The length and width are provided by the user. The waveguides are located at location and are separated by spacing. The first and second entry of number_waveguides,location, and spacing represent the input and output respectively. The curvature parameters curvature_down,curvature_up,curvature_left,curvature_right represent the shift from the linearity in the middle of each respective edge, if all 4 parameters are 0, the device is a rectangle.

The layer type is used for representation in the gdsii files and the datatype is used to define the material parameters.

Arguments

length              :: T
width               :: T 
number_waveguides   :: NTuple{2,Union{Int,Vector{Int}}} 
spacing             :: NTuple{2,Union{T,Vector{T}}}         
location            :: NTuple{2,Union{Location_Type,Vector{Location_Type}}}         
curvature_left      :: T 
curvature_right     :: T 
curvature_up        :: T 
curvature_down      :: T
layer               :: Int
datatype            :: Int

Examples

julia> d=Device(10.0u"Œºm",20.0u"Œºm")
Photonic Device
---------------
length: 10.0 Œºm
width: 20.0 Œºm
p·µ¢‚Çô  : left-4
p‚Çí·µ§‚Çú  : right-4
curvature left: 0.0 Œºm
curvature right: 0.0 Œºm
curvature up: 0.0 Œºm
curvature down: 0.0 Œºm
layer: 0
material: 1
Shape functions: N‚ÇÅ, N‚ÇÇ, N‚ÇÉ, N‚ÇÑ
source
ImagPhotonics.Location_Type ‚Äî Type

An enumeration representing the location type of a port on a photonic device.

  • LOC_LEFT: Indicates the port is located on the left side of the device.
  • LOC_RIGHT: Indicates the port is located on the right side of the device.
  • LOC_UP: Indicates the port is located on the upper side of the device.
  • LOC_DOWN: Indicates the port is located on the lower side of the device.
source
ImagPhotonics.Monitor_Type ‚Äî Type

An enumeration representing the monitor type for a photonic device.

  • GENERIC: Indicates a generic monitor.
  • OPTIMIZATION: Indicates an optimization monitor.
  • SOURCE: Indicates a source monitor.
source

ImagPhotonics.PhotonicComponent_Type ‚Äî Type

An enumeration representing various photonic component types.

  • DEVICE: Indicates a generic photonic device.
  • WAVEGUIDE: Indicates a waveguide component.
  • TAPER: Indicates a taper component.
  • TERMINATION: Indicates a termination component.
  • RING: Indicates a ring resonator component.
source
ImagPhotonics.Port ‚Äî Type
struct Port

Represents a port location on an AbstractComponent in element units Œæ and Œ∑.

Fields:

  • x: Real number representing the x-coordinate of the port location.
  • y: Real number representing the y-coordinate of the port location.
source
ImagPhotonics.ShapeFunction2D ‚Äî Method
(sf::ShapeFunction2D)(Œæ, Œ∑, points)

Returns the value in the xy space, given the element coordinates Œæ, Œ∑ and the control points.

EXAMPLE

julia> points[0. 0.; 1. 0.; 1. 1.; 0. 1.]
4√ó2 Matrix{Float64}:
 0.0  0.0
 1.0  0.0
 1.0  1.0
 0.0  1.0
 julia> sf=ShapeFunction2D(0,0,points);
 (0.5, 0.5)
source
ImagPhotonics.Taper ‚Äî Type
Taper{T} <: AbstractComponent{T}

A concrete subtype of AbstractComponent representing a taper or termination for a waveguide in photonic devices.

Fields

  • width_initial : Initial width of the taper
  • width_final : Final width of the taper
  • length : Length of the taper
  • m : Design parameter
  • points : Array of points representing the taper
  • pin : Input port
  • pout : Output port
  • shape_function : TaperFunction object representing the shape of the taper
  • layer : Layer of the device
  • datatype : Datatype of the device

Constructors

Taper(;width_initial, width_final, length, m, layer, ComponentType, datatype, kwargs...)

Arguments

  • width_initial::T=0.5u"Œºm" : Initial width of the taper
  • width_final::T=1.0u"Œºm" : Final width of the taper
  • length::T=1.0u"Œºm" : Length of the taper
  • m::Real=0.0 : Design parameter
  • layer::Int=0 : Layer of the device
  • ComponentType::PhotonicComponent_Type=TAPER : Type of the component (Taper or Termination)
  • datatype::Int=0 : Datatype of the device
  • kwargs... : Additional keyword arguments for the TaperFunction constructor

Examples

julia> Taper()

Taper
---------------
length: 1.0 Œºm
initial width: 0.5 Œºm
final width: 1.0 Œºm
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p‚Çí·µ§‚Çú : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
layer: 0
material: 268136720

julia> Taper(ComponentType=TERMINATION)

[ Info: width_final=0.0 Œºm, the structure is termination
Termination
---------------
length: 1.0 Œºm
width: 0.5 Œºm
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p·µ¢‚Çô  : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
p‚Çí·µ§‚Çú : ImagPhotonics.Port(-1.0, 0.0)
layer: 0
material: 268158704

ImagPhotonics.TaperFunction ‚Äî Type
TaperFunction

A concrete subtype of ImagPhotonics.AbstractConnectorFunction, representing a 2D shape function. ShapeFunction2D generates the basis functions Na, and its derivatives NaŒæ and NaŒ∑ with respect to the element space Œæ and Œ∑.A mutable struct representing a taper function for a photonic device.

Fields

  • Na : Shape function
  • Na_Œæ : Tuple of functions representing the partial derivatives of Na with respect to Œæ
  • Na_Œ∑ : Tuple of functions representing the partial derivatives of Na with respect to Œ∑
  • Affinity : Affinity matrix used for affine transformations
  • _rotation : Rotation angle
  • _translation : Tuple representing translation along x and y
  • _scale : Tuple representing scaling factors along x and y
  • _mirror_x : Bool for mirroring along the x-axis
  • _mirror_y : Bool for mirroring along the y-axis
  • _operation_order : Array of transformation types representing the order of operations

Constructor

TaperFunction(L::Number, w‚ÇÅ::Number, w‚ÇÇ::Number; m = 1.0,

rotation::Real=0, translation::Tuple{Real,Real}=(0.,0.), scale::Tuple{Real,Real}=(1.,1.), mirrorx::Bool=false, mirrory::Bool=false, operationorder=[AFFINETRANSLATION,AFFINEROTATION,AFFINESCALE,AFFINEMIRRORX,AFFINEMIRRORY])

Create a taper function, which is a parametric function that represents a tapered shape (e.g., a trapezoid) with linearly changing width along its length.

Arguments

  • L: The length of the tapered shape.
  • w‚ÇÅ: The width at the starting point (x = 0) of the tapered shape.
  • w‚ÇÇ: The width at the end point (x = L) of the tapered shape.
  • m: A power factor affecting the tapering shape (default: 1.0).
  • rotation: Rotation angle in radians (default: 0).
  • translation: Translation vector as a tuple (x, y) (default: (0.,0.)).
  • scale: Scaling factor, either a single value or a tuple (xscale, yscale) (default: (1.,1.)).
  • mirror_x: Reflection along the x-axis (true/false) (default: false).
  • mirror_y: Reflection along the y-axis (true/false) (default: false).
  • operation_order: An array specifying the order of transformations (default: [AFFINETRANSLATION, AFFINEROTATION, AFFINESCALE, AFFINEMIRRORX, AFFINEMIRROR_Y]).

Returns

  • A TaperFunction object representing the tapered shape with the specified properties.
source
ImagPhotonics.Transformation_Type ‚Äî Type

An enumeration representing the transformation type for a photonic device.

  • AFFINE_TRANSLATION: Indicates an affine translation transformation.
  • AFFINE_ROTATION: Indicates an affine rotation transformation.
  • AFFINE_SCALE: Indicates an affine scale transformation.
  • AFFINE_MIRROR_X: Indicates an affine mirror transformation along the X axis.
  • AFFINE_MIRROR_Y: Indicates an affine mirror transformation along the Y axis.
source

RefractiveIndex.RefractiveMaterial ‚Äî Method
RefractiveIndex.RefractiveMaterial(name::String, dispersion::RefractiveIndex.DispersionFormula; Œªrange::Union{T,Tuple{T,T}} = 1.55u"Œºm", reference::String = "", comment::String = "", specs::Dict{Symbol, Any} = Dict{Symbol, Any}()) where T <: Union{Float64,Unitful.Quantity}

Creates a RefractiveMaterial instance with the given name, dispersion formula, wavelength range, reference, comment, and additional specifications.

#Arguments:

-name::String : Name of the refractive material. -dispersion::RefractiveIndex.DispersionFormula : Dispersion formula of the refractive material. -Œªrange::Union{T,Tuple{T,T}} : Wavelength range of the refractive material. If a single value is provided, it is assumed to be the upper limit, and the lower limit is set to 0. Defaults to 1.55u"Œºm. -reference::String : Reference information about the refractive material. Defaults to an empty string. -comment::String : Additional comments about the refractive material. Defaults to an empty string. -specs::Dict{Symbol, Any} : Additional specifications for the refractive material. Defaults to an empty dictionary. Returns:

A RefractiveIndex.RefractiveMaterial instance with the specified arguments.

source
ImagPhotonics.add_custom_material ‚Äî Method
add_custom_material(key::String, material::RefractiveMaterial; custom_lib::CustomLib=CUSTOM_LIB) -> Nothing

Adds a custom material to the custom library.

Arguments:

-key::String: Key to associate with the custom material. -material::RefractiveMaterial: Custom material to be added to the library. -custom_lib::CustomLib: Custom library to add the material to. Defaults to CUSTOM_LIB.

Returns:

nothing.

source
ImagPhotonics.add_marker! ‚Äî Method

function addmarker!(cell, point::Tuple{T,T}; sizemarker::T=0.1) where T <: Real

Add a square marker with a specified size to the given GDSII cell at a specified point. The marker is placed on layer 999.

Arguments:

  • cell: GDSII cell to which the marker will be added.
  • point: Tuple of real numbers representing the x and y coordinates of the center point of the marker.
  • size_marker: Optional real number specifying the side length of the square marker. Default is 0.1.

Returns:

  • The modified GDSII cell with the added marker.
source
ImagPhotonics.affinity_matrix ‚Äî Method
affinity_matrix(;rotation, translation, scale, mirror_x, mirror_y, operation_order)

Generates an affinity matrix used for affine transformations.

Arguments

  • rotation::Real=0 : Rotation angle
  • translation::Tuple{Real,Real}=(0,0) : Tuple representing translation along x and y
  • scale::Union{Real,Tuple{Real,Real}}=1 : Tuple representing scaling factors along x and y
  • mirror_x::Bool=false : Bool for mirroring along the x-axis
  • mirror_y::Bool=false : Bool for mirroring along the y-axis
  • operation_order::Array{Transformation_Type}=[AFFINE_TRANSLATION, AFFINE_ROTATION, AFFINE_SCALE, AFFINE_MIRROR_X, AFFINE_MIRROR_Y] : Array of transformation types representing the order of operations
source
ImagPhotonics.construct_device ‚Äî Method

constructdevice(device::Device; NŒæ::Int=100, N_Œ∑::Int=100)

Constructs a photonic device based on the given device object and returns a GDSTK cell object. The function takes the following arguments:

  • device: A 2D photonic device object.
  • N_Œæ: Number of Œæ points (default: 100).
  • N_Œ∑: Number of Œ∑ points (default: 100).
source
ImagPhotonics.create_custom_material ‚Äî Method
create_custom_material(name::String, dispersion::T; custom_lib::CustomLib=CUSTOM_LIB) -> RefractiveMaterial where T <: RefractiveIndex.DispersionFormula

Creates a custom material with the given name and dispersion formula and adds it to the custom library.

Arguments:

  • name::String: Name of the custom material.
  • dispersion::T: Dispersion formula of the custom material.
  • custom_lib::CustomLib: Custom library to add the material to. Defaults to CUSTOM_LIB.

Returns:

A RefractiveMaterial instance with the given name and dispersion formula.

source
ImagPhotonics.initialize_custom_lib ‚Äî Method
initialize_custom_lib(custom_lib_path::String) -> CustomLib

Initializes a custom library.

Arguments:

  • custom_lib_path::String: The path to the custom library file.

Returns:

A CustomLib instance with the given path and an empty dictionary if the file does not exist, or a dictionary containing the custom materials if the file exists.

source
ImagPhotonics.is_squarematrix ‚Äî Method

function is_squarematrix(A::Matrix)

Return true if the matrix A is square.

Examples

Copy code
julia> is_squarematrix(Matrix(undef, 3, 2))
false

julia> is_squarematrix(Matrix(undef, 3, 3))
true

loadcustomlib() -> Nothing Loads the custom library from the file.

source
ImagPhotonics.normal_to_device ‚Äî Function
normal_to_device(device::Device, port_number::Int=1, connector::Connector_Type=C_INPUT)

Computes the normal vector to the surface of a 2D photonic device at the specified connection point.

Arguments:

  • device: A 2D photonic device object (instance of Device).
  • port_number: The port number to compute the normal vector for (default: 1). It should be within the range of input or output ports.
  • connector: The connector type, either CINPUT or COUTPUT (default: C_INPUT).

Returns:

  • A normal vector (as an array) to the surface at the specified connection point.
source
ImagPhotonics.normalize ‚Äî Method

normalize(x::Unitful.AbstractQuantity) normalize(x::Matrix{Unitful.AbstractQuantity})

Return a multiplicative identity for any x of type Unitful.AbstractType.

Examples

```julia-repl julia> normalize(1u"m") 1.0 m

julia> normalize(Matrix{u"m"}(I, 2, 2)) 2√ó2 Matrix{Quantity{Float64, ùêã, Unitful.FreeUnits{(m,), ùêã, nothing}}}: 1.0 m 0.0 m 0.0 m 1.0 m

source
ImagPhotonics.position_device_ports ‚Äî Method
position_device_ports(length::T, width::T, spacing::T, number::Int, location::Location_Type) where T <: Unitful.Quantity

Returns an array of Port objects that represent the positions of waveguides in the square element interval Œæ√óŒ∑ ‚àà [-1,1]√ó[-1,1] on a 2D photonic device. The function takes the following arguments:

  • length: Length of the device.
  • width: Width of the device.
  • spacing: Spacing between the waveguides.
  • number: Number of waveguides.
  • location: Location of the waveguides on the device (LOCLEFT, LOCRIGHT, LOCUP, LOCDOWN).
source
ImagPhotonics.remove_custom_material ‚Äî Function
remove_custom_material(key::String, index::Union{Int, Nothing, typeof(ALL)}=nothing; custom_lib::CustomLib=CUSTOM_LIB) -> Nothing

Removes a custom material from the custom library.

Arguments:

-key::String: Key associated with the custom material. -index::Union{Int, Nothing, typeof(ALL)}: Index of the custom material in the case of a vector of materials. If nothing, an error will be raised if trying to remove an element from a vector of RefractiveMaterials. If ALL, all materials associated with the key will be removed. Defaults to nothing. -custom_lib::CustomLib: Custom library to remove the material from. Defaults to CUSTOM_LIB.

Returns:

nothing.

source
ImagPhotonics.save_custom_lib ‚Äî Method
save_custom_lib() -> Nothing

Saves the custom library to the file.

Returns:

nothing.

source
ImagPhotonics.update_affinity_matrix! ‚Äî Method
update_affinity_matrix!(tf::AbstractConnectorFunction;
    rotation::Union{Real,Nothing}=nothing,
    translation::Union{Tuple{Real,Real},Nothing}=nothing,
    scale::Union{Real,Tuple{Real,Real},Nothing}=nothing,
    mirror_x::Union{Bool,Nothing}=nothing,
    mirror_y::Union{Bool,Nothing}=nothing,
    operation_order::Union{Array{Transformation_Type},Nothing}=nothing)

Update the affinity matrix of a connector function with new transformation parameters. If a parameter is not provided, the existing value will be used.

Arguments

  • tf: The connector function object.
  • rotation: Rotation angle in radians (optional).
  • translation: Translation vector as a tuple (x, y) (optional).
  • scale: Scaling factor, either a single value or a tuple (xscale, yscale) (optional).
  • mirror_x: Reflection along the x-axis (true/false) (optional).
  • mirror_y: Reflection along the y-axis (true/false) (optional).
  • operation_order: An array specifying the order of transformations (optional).

Returns

  • The updated connector function object.
source
ImagPhotonics.update_custom_lib ‚Äî Function
update_custom_lib(custom_lib_path::Union{Nothing,String}=nothing; custom_lib::Union{Nothing,Dict{String, Union{RefractiveMaterial, Vector{RefractiveMaterial}}}}=nothing) -> Nothing

Updates a custom library.

Arguments:

-custom_lib_path::Union{Nothing,String}: Path to the custom library file. If nothing, reinitializes the DEFAULTCUSTOMLIBPATH. Defaults to nothing. customlib::Union{Nothing,Dict{String, Union{RefractiveMaterial, Vector{RefractiveMaterial}}}}: A custom library to be used. If nothing, the current library is used. Defaults to nothing.

Returns:

  • nothing
source
ImagPhotonics.update_shape_function ‚Äî Method
update_shape_function(order::NTuple{4,Int}, length_device::T, width_device::T) where T

Updates the shape function of a 2D photonic device based on the given order. The function takes the following arguments:

  • order: A tuple containing the order of curvatures (down, left, up, right).
  • length_device: Length of the device.
  • width_device: Width of the device.

Returns a shape function and a matrix of points representing the updated shape function.

source
ImagPhotonics.visualize_cell ‚Äî Function
visualize_cell(cell [,transform])

Visualize the cell generated using the python package gdstk. The code only accepts object of type

  • gdstk.polygons
  • gdstk.paths
  • gdstk.references

The object gdstk.curve is not supported and it has to be converted into a polygon first

...

Arguments

  • cell::PyObject: the library object containing all the design information
  • transform::Array{Real,2}: it is a 2x3 transformation matrix containg the translation information in the last column

...

Examples

julia> visualize_cell(layout)
julia> œï=œÄ/2;
julia> dx=1; dy=0;
julia> transform= [cos(œï) -sin(œï) dx;sin(œï) cos(œï),dy]
2x3 Array{Float64,2}:
 0 -1  1
 1  0  0
julia> visualize_cell(layout,transform)

See also visualize_gds

source
ImagPhotonics.visualize_gds ‚Äî Method
visualize_gds(layout)

Visualize the layout generated using the python package gdstk. Layout is a PyObject <gdstk.Library> and it contains an array of cells PyObject <gdstk.Cells>

Arguments

  • layout::PyObject: the library object containing all the design information

Examples

julia> visualize_gds(layout)

See also visualize_cell
